title: Perplexity’s Bold Approach to Election Tracking with AI
description: In this episode, we dive into how Perplexity, a controversial AI search engine, took on real-time election tracking while other AI companies held back. We explore the risks, partnerships, and legal controversies surrounding Perplexity’s Election Information Hub, with insights from a recent Wired article.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we’re diving into a bold move by Perplexity, an AI search engine that stepped up to provide real-time election tracking for the US 2024 presidential election—a path most AI companies chose to avoid.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Our source for this story is Wired’s recent article titled 'Perplexity Dove Into Real-Time Election Tracking While Other AI Companies Held Back,' authored by Wired's team. You can find the full article on Wired.com.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Perplexity has been in the news for its unconventional approach to delivering information. They have a track record of scraping content, even from behind paywalls, which has led to controversy and even legal issues. But this time, Perplexity decided to venture into the complex world of live election tracking with an Election Information Hub that promises voters reliable, real-time updates on issues and results.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Unlike other AI platforms, Perplexity promised that its tool would offer a dependable source for understanding key election issues, making informed voting decisions, and tracking results as they came in. The Election Information Hub was built with real-time data sources, including partnerships with Democracy Works and the Associated Press, known for providing accurate election information. This was essential to prevent AI hallucinations—where models fill gaps by inventing details—which has been a persistent challenge in the field.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So why did Perplexity take this risk while other companies like OpenAI and Google held back? According to Wired, OpenAI’s ChatGPT Search and Google’s search engine both limited their AI responses on political topics. OpenAI even declined requests for candidate endorsements or recommendations. Google, on the other hand, explicitly limited AI’s involvement in election-related searches, recognizing that even small errors can create significant misinterpretations.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Interestingly, Perplexity’s CEO, Aravind Srinivas, leaned into this spotlight. He even posted a message on X, formerly Twitter, suggesting that Perplexity was the only AI capable of providing accurate election tracking. In a twist, Srinivas also made an offer to The New York Times during a labor strike, suggesting that Perplexity’s technology could provide ‘infrastructure’ support—not AI-generated content. This was a calculated move to gain visibility for Perplexity while highlighting its infrastructure capabilities.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: While Perplexity’s tool didn’t make significant errors during its election tracking, this was largely due to its reduced reliance on AI-generated summaries, instead pulling from directly sourced information. This caution was necessary, as Perplexity is already facing scrutiny over its AI summarizing content from other publishers, with reports that it even ignores certain web-scraping restrictions. In fact, Wired reported that Perplexity is currently navigating legal issues from outlets like Forbes and News Corp for summarizing articles without permission and, at times, fabricating information or citing inaccurate sources.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: On the business side, Perplexity’s bold strategies appear to be paying off. The company is finalizing a new funding round, reportedly valued at around $9 billion. This valuation reflects investor confidence despite the controversial aspects of their approach, suggesting that Perplexity’s ability to quickly deliver summarized, real-time information is a valuable asset.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: However, this high-speed approach has raised ethical concerns. As Wired pointed out, using AI to summarize articles can result in unintended inaccuracies, especially without proper safeguards. Perplexity seems to be aware of these risks, but the question remains: can they navigate the fine line between innovation and intellectual property rights, especially in such a high-stakes arena as political information?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: For now, Perplexity’s Election Information Hub shows that they’re ready to disrupt the field, even if it means pushing boundaries. But the ongoing legal battles and ethical questions will likely influence their path forward. Will Perplexity adjust its strategies to respect content creators more, or will it continue to challenge these standards in favor of a more open web?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s all for today’s episode. Thanks for joining me on 'Life is Artificial.' I hope this gave you some insight into how AI is impacting real-world events and where it may lead us in the future. For the full story, you can check out the Wired article titled 'Perplexity Dove Into Real-Time Election Tracking While Other AI Companies Held Back.'

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Until next time, stay curious and keep exploring the world of AI.
